body:
@chrisvest 

Another point: i see that the only reason why we have a default handle instance per pooled element is to track the state per each pooled object - but is a waste in many ways.
Most of the time we uses the unguarded recycling which doesn't track it (!).
We can get rid of this limit - or let the unguarded recycling to become a full citizen/type instead which:
1. doesn't need to store release/load acquire per pooled instance state
2. doesn't need to allocate an additional indirection per pooled object

This one, plus the changes to be more "local pooling first" should be enough to fill the gap claimed in this issue.
FYI @He-Pin the recycling itself for event loops virtual threads has been functionally fixed by @yawkat
Thanks, I want to leverage it, you can see, in Pekko, there is an `Envelope`, which is allocated for every `send`.

@georgebanasios 

I've added few commits into https://github.com/franz1981/netty/commits/4.2_recycler/ getting some mixed feelings:
- 54e8a1dde6931d8e3fa0b09876b16680a0c0edde already improve performance of `Recycler` halving its latency cost (clearly: by changing how it works!) -> you can give it a shot for the adaptive pr - which I still have to review

I need to go deeper in this, to understand what's going on.

For reference both the previous commits are double as costly as the local array q + mpsc q one, whilst `4.2` was 4 times worse in my machine.

@franz1981 This: https://github.com/netty/netty/commit/54e8a1dde6931d8e3fa0b09876b16680a0c0edde is intended to be used in the `ThreadLocalCache` just like my commit, same like we have now the local array q + mpsc q in the adaptive pr?

> This: https://github.com/netty/netty/commit/54e8a1dde6931d8e3fa0b09876b16680a0c0edde is intended to be used in the ThreadLocalCache just like my commit, same like we have now the local array q + mpsc q in the adaptive pr?

It's to replace the existing `4.2` `Recycler` in the adaptive allocator, but is not removing yet the need of `FastThreadLocal` because IDK yet if it's the performance bottleneck there.
ATM the purpose of this investigation is to learn with precision why the `Recycler` is not as good as the local + external q in that measure: 4X slower is just too much.
2X, is better, but I think we can get better on it.
And in the grand scheme, if we improve it that much, other code paths will benefit.

issue.title: Improve Recycler's local pooling

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

Existing Recycler has bad performance in the thread-local case

Modification:

Allow Recycler to drop fast-thread-local usage and enable fully unguarded recycles i.e. no wrapper handling

Result:

Fixes #15604

- [x] Implement correctly https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/15610#issuecomment-3258147192
- [x] Add tests for missing recycler types
- [x] Implementing a mechanism to allow pinned recyclers to gc their owner + tests
- [ ] Improve performance for the #15419
